content:
Hello! (My first post here)

I'm making an initial foray into teaching with Lean this spring, working with an advanced CS/Math undergraduate. The student has experience with natural deduction and informal proof, but not with Lean.

I wonder, does anyone have any ideas for an appropriately-sized project that an enthusiastic but inexperienced student might be able to complete in one semester? Bonus points if the project could constitute an open source contribution somewhere - the student is aiming to get into a graduate program, and could use the CV item. More quotidian things (like "work through this book and update it to Lean 4") are fine.

Self-promo: I am searching for somebody to prove the context-free pumping lemma.
https://github.com/madvorak/grammars/blob/main/src/context_free/cfgPumping.lean
Do you want to do CS or math? You don't give your own background.

@Martin Dvořák - thanks! The book looks like a great resource. No promises about the pumping lemma, but I'll take a closer look when I can.

@Kevin Buzzard - Oops, should have made a better introduction. Here's my home page: grahamlk.me. I'm coming at this from a mostly math (logic) background. I've bumped up against CS topics from time to time, but that's not main area.
They were just quick suggestions. Feel free to ignore them.
